title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
Welcome

Today’s goal: become confident using AI to accelerate data analysis.


What we’ll do (4 hours):
 Foundations of how AI works
 Gemini capabilities + tokens + pricing basics
 Prompting patterns for ornithological analysis
 Hands‑on labs with SFBBO survey datasets
 Building reusable analysis workflows

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
Workshop Agenda (4 Hours)


Hour 1 — Foundations
 AI/LLM basics, tokens, context windows
 Gemini model family and safety

Hour 2 — Prompting for Analysis
 Data understanding, EDA prompts
 Asking for charts, summaries, and insights

Hour 3 — Tooling + Workflows
 CSV + notebook workflows
 Iterative refinement and validation

Hour 4 — Capstone + Q&A
 Mini‑project and best practices
 Pitfalls, governance, next steps

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
Learning Outcomes
By the end, you will:
 Explain what tokens and context windows are
 Craft high‑quality prompts for bird data analysis tasks
 Build a repeatable analysis workflow with Gemini
 Validate outputs and reduce hallucinations

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
Quick Poll: Your AI Experience

  Have you used AI tools (ChatGPT, Gemini, Claude)?
  
     Yes, regularly
     Yes, once or twice
     No, never
     Not sure

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
What is Gemini?
Gemini is Google’s family of multimodal AI models that can reason over text, code, and structured data (and more).

Key strengths for SFBBO staff:
 Summarization — distill years of survey data
 Pattern detection — find migration trends
 Code generation — automate data cleaning
 Narrative storytelling — write reports and grant summaries

title: AI for Data Analysis
section: AI vs LLM: What’s the Difference?
text:
AI vs LLM: What’s the Difference?
AI (Artificial Intelligence) is a broad field:
 Any technology that performs tasks humans usually do
 Includes chatbots, recommendation engines, image recognition, game-playing bots

LLM (Large Language Model) is a specific type of AI:
 Uses text data to understand and generate language
 Trained on billions of words from the internet, books, code, etc.
 Gemini, ChatGPT, and Claude are all LLMs


Think of it like birdwatching: All LLMs are AI, but not all AI is LLMs—just like all shorebirds are birds, but not all birds are shorebirds!

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
Discuss with Your Neighbor (2 min)

  Which of these is an LLM?
  
     Spotify recommendation
     Google image search
     Gemini
     ChatGPT
  








Tip


Answers: Gemini and ChatGPT are LLMs (both are correct!) Why? They use language understanding, not image recognition or recommendation algorithms.

title: AI for Data Analysis
section: How LLMs Are Created — Part 1: Training Data
text:
How LLMs Are Created — Part 1: Training Data
Step 1: Collect massive amounts of text
 Billions of pages from the internet, books, research papers, code repositories
 Remove spam, personal data, and low-quality text
 Curate a balanced dataset covering many topics

Why this matters: - Quality data = better understanding of language patterns - Diverse data = model works across many domains (including ornithology!) - Quantity = model learns more nuanced patterns

title: AI for Data Analysis
section: How LLMs Are Created — Part 2: Training Process
text:
How LLMs Are Created — Part 2: Training Process
Step 2: The model learns through prediction
Imagine teaching a bird watcher to identify species. You show examples:
"This small brown bird with a ___ is a House Sparrow."
The model learns: “The blank word should be ‘curved bill’ or ‘striped head’.”

Same concept for LLMs:

Show the model: “The Dunlin (Calidris alpina) is a small ___”
Model predicts: “shorebird”
If wrong, adjust so it gets better next time
Repeat billions of times



This teaches the model patterns about what words go together and what makes sense.

title: AI for Data Analysis
section: How LLMs Are Created — Part 3: Fine-tuning & Safety
text:
How LLMs Are Created — Part 3: Fine-tuning & Safety
Step 3: Make it helpful and safe
 Human experts label examples of good vs. bad responses
 Train the model to prefer helpful, accurate, honest answers
 Add safeguards against harmful outputs

Real example for SFBBO:

Train on bird survey best practices
Reward: “Here’s how to analyze tern breeding success using SFBBO protocols”
Penalize: Made-up conservation statistics

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
How LLMs Are Created — Summary
The journey from data to AI assistant:



 Gather text data
 Learn patterns through prediction
 Optimize and refine
 Add human feedback
 Safety testing


The model learns to: - Understand context and meaning - Follow instructions - Admit uncertainty - Write in different styles - Reason through problems

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
Think-Pair-Share: Real-World Example
Scenario: You ask Gemini: “List all Dunlin observations in SFBBO’s 2024 database.”

Think (30 sec): What could go wrong?


Pair (1 min): Turn to a neighbor and share concerns.


Share: Let’s hear 2-3 concerns…








Warning


Key insight: Gemini can’t access SFBBO’s private database—it only knows what you tell it. Always provide your data explicitly!

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
What LLMs Can Do Well
 Text understanding & analysis - Summarize SFBBO survey notes - Extract key information from datasets

 Writing & communication - Draft reports, grant proposals, newsletters - Generate multiple versions or reframings


 Coding & automation - Write Python/R code for data cleaning - Generate SQL queries for databases


 Brainstorming & patterns - Suggest research directions - Identify correlations in data

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
What LLMs Cannot Do
 Access real-time information - No internet browsing (unless specifically enabled) - Doesn’t know events after training date - Can’t check current SFBBO monitoring sites

 Perform complex math reliably - May make arithmetic errors - Struggles with multi-step calculations - Always verify statistics yourself!


 Have personal experiences or emotions - Can’t actually go birdwatching - Can’t feel passion for conservation - Simulates understanding, doesn’t truly “know”


 Access external data without you providing it - Doesn’t have access to SFBBO’s internal databases - Can’t pull up historical records on its own - You must share the data to analyze

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
What LLMs Cannot Do (cont.)
 Guarantee accuracy or avoid hallucinations - Can confidently state false information - May invent citations or statistics - Always fact-check outputs!

 Understand context you don’t explicitly provide - Doesn’t know SFBBO protocols unless you explain them - Doesn’t know your local bird species distributions - Works best when you give complete context


 Make final scientific decisions - LLM suggestions need expert review - Should inform, not replace, your expertise - Always validate with field data

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
Quick Check: Spot the Hallucination

  Which statement about California Gulls is FALSE?
  
    1. State bird of Utah
    2. Nest exclusively on SF Bay islands
    3. Medium-sized gull with yellow-green legs
    4. Population stable since 1980
  








Warning


Answers: #2 (they nest inland at lakes, not exclusively on Bay islands) and #4 (populations have fluctuated significantly!)
Even confident-sounding facts about local species need verification!

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
LLM Capabilities & Limitations — Quick Reference








Task
LLM Capability
Your Role




Summarize survey data
 Excellent
Review for accuracy


Analyze bird counts
 Good
Validate statistics


Write grants or reports
 Excellent
Edit and fact-check


Generate analysis code
 Good
Test and verify


Real-time species alerts
 Cannot do
You must set up


Complex statistical tests
 Risky
You should code/verify


Interpret species biology
 Good
Confirm with literature


Make conservation decisions
 Cannot do
That’s your expertise

title: AI for Data Analysis
section: Poll: Which Would YOU Trust Gemini With?
text:
Poll: Which Would YOU Trust Gemini With?

  Which task would you trust Gemini with?
  
     Drafting a grant
     Writing Python code
     Statistical analysis
     Conservation decisions

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
How AI Works (High‑Level)
LLMs are trained to predict the next token in a sequence.

They learn statistical patterns from large corpora to generate useful outputs.








Note


You provide: instructions + data + constraints
Model returns: a best‑guess completion

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
Tokens, Context, and Cost
 Token ≈ a chunk of text (word piece)
 Context window = max tokens a model can see at once
 Costs scale with input + output tokens

Rule of thumb: \[\text{Cost} \propto \text{input tokens} + \text{output tokens}\]

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
Prompting Basics
Great prompts include:
 Role — who the model is
 Task — what to do
 Data — input
 Constraints — format, length, method
 Examples — optional but powerful

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
Interactive: Build a Prompt Together
Let’s co-create a prompt for Gemini!

I’ll say: “Analyze bird count data.”  Too vague!


Who can help make it better?

What role should Gemini play?
What exactly should it analyze?
What format for output?



Better version: “You are a conservation analyst at SFBBO. Analyze this CSV of shorebird counts. Highlight species with >20% population decline and suggest management actions. Format as bullet points.”

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
Exercise 1: Prompt Template
 Your Turn: Copy this template and customize for your SFBBO data:


Copy to Gemini

Role: You are an expert ornithologist and data analyst 
working with the San Francisco Bay Bird Observatory (SFBBO).

Task: Summarize key trends in the bird survey dataset.

Data: <paste CSV or description here>

Constraints:
- Provide 5 bullet-point insights
- Suggest 2 visualization ideas
- Note any data quality issues
- Highlight conservation implications for SF Bay wetlands

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
Gemini Model Options (Overview)
Choose based on your analysis needs:
 Latency — speed for quick queries
 Context length — how much survey data fits
 Cost — budget for large datasets
 Quality — reasoning depth for complex analysis

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
Pair Activity: Pick Your Model
Scenario 1: You need to analyze 5 years of SFBBO shorebird counts (~50k rows) to write a grant.
Scenario 2: You’re on a field trip and want a quick summary of today’s sightings.

Discussion: Which Gemini version for each scenario? Talk with your neighbor for 1 minute.








Tip


Scenario 1: Larger model (more reasoning, bigger context). Scenario 2: Faster model (speed matters more).

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
Quick Break Reflection
Before we move to prompting, reflect:

What’s one thing Gemini could help you with in your bird work?


(You can write it down—we’ll revisit this in the capstone!)

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
Hour 2 — Prompting for EDA
Tasks Gemini can help with for SFBBO data:
 Column summaries and data dictionary generation
 Missing value analysis (incomplete surveys)
 Outlier detection (unusual counts, rare species)
 Hypothesis generation (population trends, habitat preferences)

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
Exercise 3: EDA Prompt
 Your Turn: Copy this prompt to analyze SFBBO survey data:


Copy to Gemini

You are an expert ornithologist working with SFBBO (San Francisco Bay 
Bird Observatory). I'm sharing a waterbird survey dataset.

TASK: Perform an exploratory data analysis and provide:

1. **Data Overview**
   - Number of records, date range, locations covered
   - List of species observed with frequency counts

2. **Data Quality Assessment**
   - Missing values by column
   - Potential data entry errors or outliers
   - Consistency issues (e.g., species naming)

3. **Initial Insights**
   - Top 5 most frequently observed species
   - Location with highest species diversity
   - Any notable rare species sightings

4. **Visualization Recommendations**
   - Suggest 3 charts with specific axis mappings
   - Explain what each would reveal about SF Bay bird populations

Output as structured markdown with clear headers.

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
Exercise 5: Analysis Prompt
Use this prompt with the shorebird dataset (or save for later):


Copy to Gemini

You are an ornithologist at SFBBO analyzing shorebird migration data.

Using the provided dataset, complete these tasks:

1. **Summarize the dataset**
   - Total observations by species and site
   - Weekly survey coverage

2. **Identify 3 patterns or anomalies**
   - Look for unusual count spikes or drops
   - Note any correlation with weather, tide, or moon phase
   - Flag potential data quality issues

3. **Ecological interpretation**
   - What do the patterns suggest about shorebird use of SF Bay?
   - How do counts compare between sites?

4. **Propose 2 conservation-relevant next steps**
   - What additional data would strengthen this analysis?
   - What management questions could this data help answer?

Format: Use headers, bullet points, and bold for key findings.

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
Prompting Patterns — The Big Three
Master these patterns and you’ll level up your prompts:

 Decompose — Break complex tasks into steps


Copy to Gemini

First, summarize species counts by SFBBO monitoring site.
Then, analyze weekly trends for the top 3 shorebird species.
Finally, identify correlations with tide and weather variables.

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
Prompting Patterns — The Big Three (cont.)
 Constrain — Set specific output requirements


Copy to Gemini

Provide exactly 5 bullet points, max 15 words each.
Focus only on shorebird species in the Scolopacidae family.
Use scientific names in parentheses after common names.

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
Prompting Patterns (cont.)
 Verify — Request self-assessment


Copy to Gemini

List your assumptions about the SFBBO dataset.
Rate your confidence (high/medium/low) for each insight.
Note which findings need field verification by SFBBO staff.

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
Pair Challenge: Apply the Patterns
Task: You want Gemini to analyze tern breeding success.

With a neighbor: - Which pattern would help? (Decompose, Constrain, Verify?) - Why? - How would you apply it?


Answer: Likely all three! Decompose (multiple steps), Constrain (specific metrics), Verify (confidence levels).

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
Hour 3 — Tooling + Workflows
Typical SFBBO analysis workflow:

 Load survey data in a notebook
 Use Gemini to generate hypotheses about patterns
 Validate with Python/R code
 Iterate based on results

title: AI for Data Analysis
section: Real-World Scenario: Would You Catch This?
text:
Real-World Scenario: Would You Catch This?
You ask Gemini: “My bird survey shows a 400% increase in Snowy Egrets from Jan to Feb. Is this migration or climate change?”
Gemini responds: “This dramatic increase suggests climate-driven habitat expansion.”

What’s missing? (Think 30 seconds…)








Warning


Gemini didn’t ask: Did you check your data entry? Is that 4x real? Could it be observer differences? You need to validate first!

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
Safe and Reliable Use






Important


Always validate AI outputs against your field expertise!




 Cross‑check species IDs and counts with raw data
 Keep prompts specific to SFBBO survey protocols
 Ask for sources or ecological rationale
 Use small, testable analytical steps

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
Handling Hallucinations
AI can make mistakes with bird data. Mitigation strategies:
 Provide data explicitly — don’t assume it knows SFBBO protocols
 Ask for uncertainty — “How confident are you?”
 Request calculations — have it show the math
 Validate with code — quick sanity checks

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
Exercise 6: Uncertainty Prompt
 Your Turn:


Copy to Gemini

Analyze this SFBBO bird count data. For each conclusion:
- State your confidence level (high/medium/low)
- Explain what evidence supports it
- Note what could disprove it
- Identify what additional SFBBO data would help confirm the finding

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
Exercise 7: Structured Checklist
 Your Turn: Convert a narrative prompt into a structured checklist prompt.

Before (vague):
Analyze the Ridgway's Rail population data.


After (structured):


Copy to Gemini

Analyze Ridgway's Rail (Rallus obsoletus) survey data from SFBBO's 
long-term monitoring program.

Complete this checklist:
□ 1) Define the population metric (individuals, breeding pairs, or call responses)
□ 2) Calculate year-over-year population change (%) for each marsh
□ 3) Segment by region (North Bay vs. South Bay)
□ 4) Identify peak detection months
□ 5) Flag any surveys with zero detections (potential concern)
□ 6) Note correlation with tide levels during surveys
□ 7) Compare with historical SFBBO baselines if patterns emerge

Output format: Numbered findings with supporting statistics.

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
Hour 4 — Capstone Project
Choose one project relevant to SFBBO’s mission:



 Waterfowl Trends
Analyze duck & goose populations across SF Bay wetlands over 5 years

 Raptor Survey
Examine seasonal patterns in hawk and falcon sightings at SFBBO sites

 Breeding Success
Compare nesting success rates across habitats



Deliverables:
 Prompt set (3-5 well-crafted prompts)
 Findings summary (key insights)
 Next‑step recommendations for SFBBO

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
Exercise 8: Capstone Prompt


Copy to Gemini

You are a wildlife data analyst at SFBBO (San Francisco Bay Bird Observatory).

PROJECT: Waterfowl Population Trends Analysis

CONTEXT:
- Data source: SFBBO annual January waterfowl census
- Time period: 2021-2025
- Goal: Inform wetland management and conservation decisions

ANALYSIS REQUIRED:

1. **Trend Analysis**
   - Calculate year-over-year changes for each species
   - Identify any concerning declines (>20%) or notable increases
   - Note the 5-year trend direction for each species

2. **Habitat Comparison**
   - Compare waterfowl use between freshwater and salt pond habitats
   - Identify which species show habitat preferences

3. **Disturbance Assessment**
   - Correlate counts with human disturbance levels
   - Assess impact of water level changes
   - Recommend management interventions

4. **Conservation Recommendations**
   - Prioritize species/sites for enhanced monitoring
   - Suggest habitat improvements
   - Identify data gaps for SFBBO to address

OUTPUT: Executive summary (1 page) + detailed findings with statistics.

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
Exercise 9: Raptor Analysis Prompt


Copy to Gemini

You are an ornithologist at SFBBO analyzing fall raptor migration data 
from Hawk Hill in the Marin Headlands.

Using the dataset, provide:

1. **Migration Summary**
   - Total count by species
   - Peak migration dates for each species
   - Species diversity and dominance patterns

2. **Weather Correlations**
   - How do wind direction and speed affect flight counts?
   - Does visibility or cloud cover impact detection?
   - Identify optimal survey conditions

3. **Temporal Patterns**
   - Compare morning vs. midday vs. afternoon flights
   - Weekly trends through the season
   - Any notable late-season observations?

4. **Conservation Insights**
   - Which species should SFBBO prioritize for monitoring?
   - Are any species showing unusual patterns?
   - Recommendations for next year's survey effort

Format as a structured report suitable for SFBBO's newsletter.

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
Exercise 10: Breeding Analysis Prompt


Copy to Gemini

You are analyzing SFBBO's breeding bird territory mapping data.

Provide a comprehensive breeding season summary:

1. **Nesting Success Overview**
   - Calculate nest success rate by species (% with confirmed nests)
   - Calculate productivity (fledglings per successful nest)
   - Identify most and least successful species

2. **Habitat Analysis**
   - Compare success rates across habitat types
   - Calculate average territory size by species
   - Which habitats support highest species diversity?

3. **Threat Assessment**
   - Categorize and quantify threats
   - Which species/sites face highest threat levels?
   - Correlation between threats and nest failure

4. **Site Comparison**
   - Rank SFBBO sites by breeding bird diversity
   - Identify sites with conservation concern
   - Recommend priority sites for protection

5. **Management Recommendations**
   - Actions to improve nest success
   - Threat mitigation strategies
   - Data collection improvements for next season

Output as a formal report suitable for SFBBO's annual summary.

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
Prompt Engineering Cheatsheet






Remember: Clarity > cleverness







 State the desired output format explicitly
 Provide all necessary SFBBO data (don’t assume knowledge)
 Specify time period, site, and species scope
 Ask for confidence levels and assumptions
 Request specific numbers, not vague qualifiers

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
Quick Reference: Data Cleaning


Copy to Gemini

Review this SFBBO bird survey CSV for data quality issues. 

Flag the following:
- Duplicate records (same date, site, species, count)
- Impossible counts (negative or >10,000 for non-colonial species)
- Misspelled species names or invalid species codes
- Dates outside the survey period
- Missing required fields (date, site, species, count)
- Inconsistent site naming

Output as a table of issues with row numbers, issue type, and suggested fixes.

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
Quick Reference: Summary Stats


Copy to Gemini

Calculate for each species in this SFBBO dataset:
- Total count across all surveys
- Mean count per survey
- Standard deviation
- Minimum and maximum counts
- Number of surveys where detected (frequency of occurrence)
- Percentage of surveys with detections

Format as a markdown table sorted by total count descending.
Include a brief interpretation highlighting:
- Most abundant species
- Most consistently detected species
- Species with high variability (potential concern)

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
Quick Reference: Conservation


Copy to Gemini

Based on these SFBBO population trends, identify:

1. **Species of Conservation Concern**
   - Any species declining >15% year-over-year
   - Species with high count variability (CV > 50%)
   - Species absent from historical sites

2. **Potential Causes**
   - Habitat changes at SFBBO monitoring sites
   - Weather/climate factors affecting SF Bay
   - Human disturbance patterns

3. **Recommended Actions**
   - Priority species for enhanced SFBBO monitoring
   - Sites needing management intervention
   - Data collection protocol improvements

Cite specific numbers from the data to support each conclusion.
Reference SFBBO's conservation mission where relevant.

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
Governance and Ethics






Data Responsibility for SFBBO






 Avoid sharing sensitive location data (rare species nest sites)
 Follow SFBBO’s data sharing policies
 Document AI model usage in methods sections
 Keep SFBBO scientists in the loop for all conclusions

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
Final Reflection: Your AI Journey

  How do you feel about using Gemini for your bird work?
  
     Confident
     Curious - want practice
     Still learning
     Need more guidance

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
Closing + Resources
Next steps for your SFBBO work:
 Practice with your own SFBBO survey datasets
 Build a prompt library for common analyses
 Share learnings with the SFBBO team
 Integrate Gemini into eBird and SFBBO data workflows

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
Action Items: Go Forth!
This week, try:


Ask Gemini to summarize one SFBBO dataset




Use one of the three prompting patterns we learned




Validate the output—did it match reality?




Share your experience with the SFBBO team

title: AI for Data Analysis
text:
Thank You

Happy birding and AI-powered data analysis! 


Questions? Discussion? 


Learn more at sfbbo.org
